abstract.p: Lighting in buildings can exert a large influence on the comfort, well-being, and health of occupants. A window plays a major role in providing both natural lighting in buildings and a view out, so that occupants can keep in touch with the external environment. Thus, it is essential to understand what the visual requirements are to meet occupants’ needs and how window views could affect those requirements. This study aims to reveal occupant perception on window views and to identify its effects on the assessment of glare from windows. This paper presents the results from the experiment conducted in a chamber with a simulated window, which can render various window views and luminance conditions. Forty-eight subjects participated in the experiment. The results show the evidence that the glare sensation of occupants could vary with the occupant’s perception on window views under the same luminous conditions. A discomfort glare index that predicts a subjective discomfort glare as a function of background and window luminances, position index, and perception on window views, has been developed by this study. A comparison between the developed and existing glare prediction models was discussed in this paper.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Windows can have significant implications for buildings and their occupants. The window plays a major role in controlling the amount of daylight transfer between the buildings and the environment. The use of daylight is of importance, as daylighting would potentially save considerable amount of lighting energy use [1–4]. The window can also engender the psychological benefits by providing a view out. Occupants’ need to communicate with the outside world, and the psychological and physiological impacts of daylight on occupants make the window an essential element in buildings.

Discomfort glare that is caused by daylight from windows is a common problem in buildings and more importantly, this has become a potential barrier to the active use of daylight by occupants. Existing models for the prediction of discomfort glare would evaluate visual environment as a function of glare source and background luminances, and the relative position and distance of observers from the glare source. However, recent studies show that the subjective evaluation of discomfort glare could also be influenced by window views [5,6].

This study aims to evaluate the occupant perception of window views by carrying out the factor analysis of the experimental data and to develop a prediction model for discomfort glare, considering the influence of the subjective evaluation of window views on discomfort glare.

sec.title: Simulated Windows and Window Views
sec.p: A simulated window that has been used in the research of discomfort glare [1,2,5,7 has been applied in this study.The simulated window can render the luminance of windows ranging from 0 to 15,000 cd·m−2 and display various window scenes such as natural and man-made scenes with near and distant views.

Table 1 shows 10 window views chosen for this study. The views were divided into distant and near views. The distant view included a three-layer image with the sky; and the near view consisted of a two-layer image without the sky. The contents of examined views included natural and man-made scenes commonly found in Korea. The average window luminances could range from 1000 to 10,000 cd·m−2 with an equal interval of 0.5 log luminance units. Table 1.
The images of the simulated view

sec.title: Evaluation of Discomfort Glare and Subjective Impression
sec.p:
The discomfort comfort scale proposed by Hopkinson et al. [8] was adopted in this study (Figure 1). Questions to evaluate discomfort glare included short descriptions of the meaning of discomfort scales in both English and Korean in order to prevent the misunderstanding of the scales. For the evaluation of subjective impressions of the window views, the semantic scales as proposed by Spencer et al. [9] were used in this study. Fig. 1.
Discomfort glare evaluation scale.

sec.title: Experimental Procedure
sec.p:
The experiment was carried out in a laboratory space and a subject took a seat on a chair at 1.5 m away from the simulated window (Figure 2). Once an experimenter explained the experimental procedure and the definition of the discomfort glare scales, the subject adapted their eyes to the lighting conditions of the laboratory for 2 min. The subject completed first the questions related to the subjective impression of given window views. The experimenter then sets up the luminance condition. The subject focused on the centre of the window for about 5 s and evaluated discomfort glare. The evaluation of discomfort glare was repeated for five luminance conditions of each view. Window views and mean luminance were randomly allocated and Figure 3 shows the experimental procedure. Fig. 2.
Experimental layout. Fig. 3.
The procedure of the experiment.

sec.title: The Subjects
sec.p: The number of participants was 48 (24 male and 24 female). The subjects were recrued from University students and their age ranged from 20 to 32. The data were analysed without discrimination of the gender, age, eyesight, and eye conditions. A financial incentive of 21 US dollar was paid to a subject for participating in the experiment.

Figure 4 is a scree plot that shows the eigenvalues of components. The eigenvalue of a component is a measure that indicates a variance of all independent variables, which is explained by the component. The eigenvalue varies little with a component number of five or higher. This implies that a component number higher than four in this case can be considered as redundant with components with higher eigenvalues. Thus, four components were selected to represent 27 variables that evaluate the subjective impressions on window views. Fig. 4.

sec.title: Discomfort Glare Prediction Model
sec.p:
A discomfort glare prediction model has been developed in this study. The model considers the influence of the subjective evaluation of a window view on discomfort glare from a window, based on factor and linear regression analyses of the experimental data obtained from this study. The prediction model developed in this study uses a Hopkinson’s daylight glare index (DGI) [11] and Nazzal’s new daylight glare index (nDGI) [12] in order to include physical parameters such as the luminance of background and glare source and the solid angle of window and glare source. The RMSE allows a term-by-term comparison of the differences between experimental data and model estimates, thus evaluating the short-term performance of a model. On the other hand, the MBE is useful to evaluate the long-term performance of a model and detects the existence of systematic over- or under-estimation tendencies. The small RMSE and MBE values of the model would indicate that the model has good predictive performance.

Table 4 compares the performance of the new and existing prediction models using the MBE and RMSE. The Nazzal’s DGI was found to over-estimate the glare sensation, compared to other models investigated in this study. The MBE and RMSE values for the Nazzal’s DGI were both highest. On the other hand, the Hopkinson’s DGI showed good prediction performance in the evaluation of discomfort glare from a window. The MBE and RMSE values for the Hopkinson’s DGI were lower than those for the Nazzal’s DGI. Table 4.

The new models were found to predict the glare sensation of subjects in a better manner compared to the existing models. For example, the prediction performance of the Nazzal’s DGI was considerably improved when subjective evaluations were included in the new model. The MBE was reduced from 22.2 to 10.4 and the RMSE value was decreased by 52%.

sec.title: Discussion and Conclusions
sec.p: The experimental results provide evidence that the glare sensation of occupants could vary with their subjective impression on the window views even under the same luminous conditions. The results also indicate that the factor analysis would be useful to reveal the subjective impression on the window views.

This study has shown that the new model developed from the analysis of experimental data can accurately predict discomfort glare from a window. The new model includes the subjective impression on the window view in the estimation of discomfort glare from the window. This study has verified that the inclusion of subjective impression factors has improved the accuracy of the prediction.

The results of this study were based on experiment using the simulated window. Although the simulated window has been widely used in discomfort glare studies and has shown reliable results, rendering images by the simulated window would be somewhat different from actual window views. This might affect the perception of subjects on the window views. Thus, further studies that investigate the influence of different window views on glare sensation under real situations are required to confirm and validate the findings of this study.
